title: 115_hr4790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Volcker Rule Regulatory Harmonization Act" and grants rulemaking authority under the Volcker Rule. The "Volcker Rule Regulatory Harmonization Act" amends section 13(b) of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to allow the Board to consult with other agencies and adopt rules or guidance to carry out the section. The Board must consider required reports when adopting rules or guidance. The Board, under the "Volcker Rule Regulatory Harmonization Act," must ensure consistent application of provisions to avoid advantages or disadvantages to affected companies and protect safety. Requirements for compliance include internal controls and recordkeeping. The Board has sole authority to issue and amend rules under this section. Any rules or guidance issued prior to this paragraph will remain in effect until the Board issues a successor rule or guidance. In examinations or supervisory duties, relevant agencies must follow applicable guidance. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission must update policies to align with new rules. Amendments to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 replace references to other agencies with "the Board." The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission must update policies to align with new rules under the amendments to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, replacing references to other agencies with "the Board." SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT; ANTI-EVASION. The amendment to subsection (e) of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 gives the appropriate federal banking agency the authority to take action if a banking entity or nonbank financial company is found to be violating restrictions or evading requirements. The amendment allows the banking entity or nonbank financial company to terminate activities and dispose of investments after a hearing. The Securities and Exchange Commission or Commodity Futures Trading Commission can take action if they suspect violations by a covered nonbank financial company. The Securities and Exchange Commission or the Commodity Futures Trading Commission can order a covered nonbank financial company to terminate activities and dispose of investments if they violate restrictions or evade requirements. A covered nonbank financial company is defined as a nonbank financial company supervised by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's authority under various acts shall not be affected by the regulations supervised by the Securities and Exchange Commission or the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. SEC. 4. EXCLUSION OF COMMUNITY BANKS FROM VOLCKER RULE. Section 13(h)(1) of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to redesignate clauses and subparagraphs, adjust margins, and make changes to trust or fiduciary capacity institutions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include new criteria for institutions with total consolidated assets exceeding $10,000,000,000 and trading assets and liabilities over 5 percent of total assets. The bill passed the House of Representatives on April 13, 2018.
